III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & COF Rule 400.10157 Health services; policies and procedures
Section (1) A facility shall establish and follow written health service
Description policies and procedures that address all of the following:
(a) Routine and emergency medical and dental care.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was not provided medical attention when bleeding rectally.
Investigation Interviews:
All interviews were conducted with MDHHS Worker face to
face at the facility on 5/23/25.
Director reported Youth complained about bleeding from his
rectum but refused medical attention. Youth refused his physical,
from Nurse and from Doctor. Finally, Youth agreed to a blood
draw before his court hearing. At the court hearing, Youth reported
he wasn’t receiving medical attention. Due to this, the judge
ordered him to go to the hospital. He went to Hurley Hospital and
was released. He came back to the facility for a couple days,
refused to take his medication and then was released home.
Director reported Nurse is at the facility daily and the Doctor is
present three days a week but also will come in if Nurse contacts
him.
Nurse reported she works daily and collaborates with Doctor who
physically is present in the building three days a week and more if
needed. Nurse reported she saw Youth on 3/10/25 and there were
no issues reported to her from him. On 4/8/25, Youth reported to
her that he had blood in his urine. On 4/10/25, Youth was seen by
Doctor and he refused the exam, but allowed a blood draw. Nurse
reported because Youth would not allow them to examine him,
she had attempted other methods to see if there was a medical
issue. Nurse reported she had given him a medical pad to put on
so that they could assess how much blood, if any was being
expelled. Nurse reported he wore it but threw it away and did not
allow them to see it. Nurse reported Doctor came in at least twice
to attempt an exam and Youth refused. Nurse reported Youth was
physically active and no other symptoms or signs of a medical
condition were present. Youth was playing sports and
weightlifting. After weightlifting in May, Youth reported he had
rectal bleeding. An exam was scheduled with Doctor and he
refused the exam and he was placed on restrictions. Nurse
reported at the court hearing on 5/13/25, Youth reported he wasn’t
getting medical attention. He was sent to Hurley Hospital. He
stayed there a few days and received medication for Ulcerative
Colitis (inflammation of the bowels). Nurse reported he was given
medication from the hospital and Doctor prescribed iron pills as
well. He refused to take the iron pills Doctor prescribed and
stated, “won’t be a guinea pig and take medication not from the
hospital.” Nurse reported she did not feel he needed to go to the
2

hospital and Doctor never assessed him as needing to go to the
hospital either.
On 6/11/25, Doctor was interviewed. Doctor reported he has
worked for the facility for about 40 years. Doctor reported he
physically comes to the facility about three times a week,
sometimes less and sometimes more depending on what the
agency needs. Doctor reported if a youth wants to see the
medical team at the facility (after intake), then they fill out a
request form, see Nurse and she completes an assessment. If
Nurse makes an assessment that the youth should see him, then
she schedules that with him (Doctor). Doctor reported there was
no serious issue to send Youth to the hospital. Youth always
refused to be examined and continued to be active in the facility.
Doctor reported on 4/24/25 Youth was seen by him and Youth
refused to allow the rectum examination. Doctor reported he
discussed bowel movements with Youth to assess possible
issues. On 5/2/25, Youth allowed him to complete a visual exam.
Youth pulled his undergarments down and Doctor reported he was
able to see that there was no bulging for possible hemorrhoids or
fissures (cracks in the skin that may produce blood). Doctor
reported he drew blood on 4/11/25 to assess whether Youth was
anemic, this would allow Doctor to assess if he was bleeding
excessively. Doctor reported the results came back normal.
Doctor reported they gave him a pad to assess bleeding, but
Youth refused to show them. Doctor reported he had no reason to
believe that Youth needed emergency health care. Youth had
never been seen with excessive bleeding, was active in sports,
and blood draw was normal. Doctor reported Youth A was
diagnosed with Ulcerative Colitis which is inflamed bowel
movements. This can also be known as Chrones. Doctor reported
this diagnosis could only be discovered through scoping. Doctor
reported there was no diagnosis of kidney stone, no infections and
normal blood draw.
I attempted to interview Youth on 6/13/25 and 6/20/25. Voicemails
were left with no return phone call.
Documents Reviewed:
• Youth intake documents were reviewed. Youth was seen
by Nurse on 3/8/25, upon intake. Youth did not provide any
medical issues. A note from Nurse stated, “Youth not co-
operative.”
• 3/10/25 the initial physical was completed by Nurse. No
medical issues noted. Youth had been using Ecstasy,
Percocet and THC. Substance abuse was noted.
3

• 3/13/25 a Health Service request was completed due to
Youth reporting “a pop in my leg when trying to stretch
before flag football…”
• I reviewed the Patient Progress Record written by Nurse.
Nurse reported staff was in contact with her on 3/13/25 and
Youth was provided ibuprofen. Youth was seen on 3/14/25
and leg was diagnosed as a mild strain. Ibuprofen
continued for five days.
• On 4/8/25, Nurse received a phone call from Mother.
Mother reported Youth had been to the emergency room
prior to being in placement and he was “internally
bleeding.” Mother reported Youth was on the street for
days, using drugs and alcohol. Youth reported at this time
that he had blood in his urine and stool but had not told
staff about this. Staff reported they had not see this either
or heard complaints. Nurse told Youth to let her know the
next time he saw blood.
• 4/10/25, Nurse requested medical information from Hurley
Hospital in relation to Mother’s phone call. Hurley
documentation reported that Youth went to the hospital but
refused to be examined; therefore no diagnosis.
• 4/22/25 Youth was seen due to Health Service Request for
a painful tooth. Mother was called and it was confirmed
Youth had an appointment scheduled in June and Mother
would call to move up the appointment and call Nurse back
with date.
• 4/24/25 Urinary analysis was completed due to previous
complaints of rectal bleeding. Lab results were pending.
• 4/28/25 lab results or Urinary Analysis was received and
sent to Doctor. Rectal exam refused by Youth and rectal
visual exam refused.
• 5/2/25 Nurse received phone call from Mother that Youth
had rectal bleeding that went through his clothes. No
request or note of this was given to her prior to this
conversation. Nurse sent referral to Doctor and gave Youth
pad for assessment. Youth was seen and pad was thrown
away before assessment. Youth reported there was only a
“couple drops” on it. Youth did not complain of any pain
except when having a bowel movement. Stool softener was
given and increased fluid intake. Restrictions were provided
for physical activities.
• 5/2/25 Doctor saw Youth and Youth reported no pain, minor
blood in undergarments. Zantac was prescribed.
• 5/13/25 Court ordered to go to hospital.
• 5/14/25 Nurse gave update to Hurley Hospital medical
professionals.
4

• 5/15/25 Nurse in contact with Hurley Hospital; Youth will
receive scope. Nurse asked for progress notes and results.
• 5/19/25 Nurse in contact with Hurley Hospital concerning
prescriptions; called Mother.
• 5/20/25 Youth returned, approved new medication at the
facility. Mother did not want any medication given to Youth
outside of what the hospital prescribed. Mother refused iron
tablets.
• 5/22/25 Nurse spoke to Mother concerning aftercare and
prescriptions. Youth was discharged.
• Hurley Hospital Documentation reported a diagnosis of
Ulcerative Colitis, inflammatory bowel disease. Treat with
anti-inflammatory drugs.
• Health Service Requests were reviewed for 5/2/25 and
5/8/25. 5/2/25 reported lab work completed and physical
restrictions until lab work is reviewed by Doctor.
• Emergency Medical Procedure policy were reviewed.
Emergency medical situations are described as difficulty
breathing, broken bones, head injuries, open wounds,
overdoes. Etc.) The nurse and doctor are to be contacted
for instructions. In life threatening situations, first aid is to
be administered if necessary as well as immediate
ambulance order.
• Routine Medical Procedure policy was reviewed. Initial
health screenings will be completed as well as routine
medical. Any youth that complains of sickness or injury will
complete a Health Service Request and staff will notify the
nurse and nurse will complete assessment and speak to
other medical staff (doctor) if further assessments are
needed. If emergency situation then the Emergency
Medical Procedure will be followed.
Analysis The agency is compliant with this rule. The agency followed their
Routine Medical Procedure policy. Youth received medical
services throughout his stay confirmed in interviews with Nurse,
Doctor, and Director as well as the Patient Progress Notes. The
medical issue never rose to following the Emergency Medical
Procedure policy.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
5

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
